Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen! So today 
i'm going to make something called yum kai dao

which just means fried egg salad. Now it's one of 
my favorite salads of all time forever and ever in

the whole wide world now why didn't i show you 
this recipe until now that's because it's in my

cookbook! It's my hot thai kitchen cookbook but i 
do think that this is a recipe that benefits from

a video demo because there's a bit of egg frying 
technique involved so i wanted to show you this as

well. Alright let's get started! Let's start 
with the dressing, this is the basic thai

"yum" dressing or salad dressing that you 
can actually just apply to any kind of salad.

We're going to start with chilies thai chilies 
and i meant to bring red ones which is typically

what's used here but i forgot and i only have 
green ones! So green one it is, same same,

a little different. So i'm going to pound that 
down first so we don't get big chunks of surprise
chilies. And try not to look at it while you pound

so it doesn't jump into your eye 
as i have discovered can happen!

And then i go look at it...kind of 
still have to see what you're doing!

Okay so now that you've got it pretty fine right 
there, you definitely don't want big chunks here

i'm going to add palm sugar and while you 
can use white sugar for this, palm sugar

adds flavor, aroma it's just so much better 
especially in a very simple dressing like

this so i'm just gonna pound that down until 
the sugar is sort of like a muddy paste oh
okay there you go and now lime juice for acid.

just swirl that pestle to dissolve the sugar and 
you definitely want fresh lime juice for this no

bottled nothing not even the powdered one which 
is not bad for some things but this you want fresh

and of course our salty fish sauce now this 
dressing normally looks a little bit redder

than this because of the chilies but oh 
well you can give this a taste if you like
oh it's perfect

salivating let's deal with our eggs all right 
so this is the hardest part of this recipe is

making the perfect thai style fried eggs for 
this salad so i'm gonna add just a lot of oil

actually into this pan here so you can use a wok 
which is helpful because it's got a rounded bottom

but if you've got a small pan like this you want 
maybe like a quarter inch so you want the eggs to

sort of be a little bit floating in the oil that's 
what's going to cause the bubbly crispy edges

we don't want western style fried eggs over here 
totally not the same so i'm going to turn this on

and i want to get this quite hot before i add 
the eggs now any eggs will do of course but i

will add some extra tips about how to choose eggs 
for maximum bubbliness and i'll put all that in

the website post one of the things i like to do to 
test oil temperatures i just grab whatever random

vegetable if it's not bubbling right away 
then it needs some time see that's still

too cold my eggs are room temperature that's 
important too because if you use eggs directly

from the fridge you drop it in the oil and 
you have only a little bit of oil the oil temp

can drop really quickly and then you don't 
have bubbliness again so okay that looks like

a good amount of excited bubbles so i'm 
going to take that out and put in my egg

there we go you can uh crack the egg 
into a bowl and then pour it in but i

find that the egg yolks tend to be off 
to one side if you do that sometimes so

so i prefer to crack it directly 
but if this makes you nervous

and this is totally normal it should bubble and 
what you'll do is take a spoon and base the oil

see bubbly white that's exactly what we 
want and baste the top to help the top cook

this pan is kind of semi 
non-stick so if your eggs are

a little bit sticking don't touch it until the 
very end let the bottom firm up once it's done

you can usually nudge it off but if you try to 
get it to release when the yolks are still really

raw then you might break the yolk and we don't 
want that i suggest doing this one egg at a time

heats a little high maybe use a 
longer spoon so it's not so hot

on your hands there you go you see all that 
crispy crispy brownness that's what you want

doneness wise you don't really want this 
completely runny because we're gonna cut this

if it's completely runny then it's just gonna 
run out all over the place so i kind of like it

moist but firm enough that when you cut 
it it's the it's still holding its shape

so how do you know kind of push it in there and 
in thailand traditionally they're completely well

done hard fried so it's not really a big deal if 
you quote unquote overcook it okay so that looks

good to me the edges are nice and crispy the top 
is a little bit done i'm just gonna take this out

yeah hopefully that's done enough maybe it needs 
a little bit i'm pressing on the yolks and i feel

like it's maybe a little too soft you can if 
you really like runny yolk do it runny and then

don't cut them when you compose the salad 
so you just leave the eggs whole but that's

not the traditional way so i want to show you 
the traditional way you could flip it over if

you really want hard hard cooked and that will

want to take that heat away from the top
